Chief Complaint: Overnight pressors were weaned to 1.5 levo, 0.3 neo,
   received 3L LR with good hemodynamic response. Patient became more
   awake, alert and responsive. C/o headache, had no evidence of
   neurological symptoms, and resolved with increased fentanyl.
   24 Hour Events:
 INVASIVE VENTILATION - START [**2129-1-24**] 10:55 AM
 MULTI LUMEN - START [**2129-1-24**] 01:30 PM
 TRANSTHORACIC ECHO - At [**2129-1-24**] 04:00 PM
 NASAL SWAB - At [**2129-1-24**] 10:00 PM

   GENERAL: Obese Caucasian Female intubated in NARD.
   HEENT: Intubated. PERRLA/EOMI.
   CARDIAC: Regular rhythm, normal rate. Normal S1, S2. No murmurs, rubs
   or [**Last Name (un) 4808**].
   LUNGS: CTAB, good air movement biaterally.
   ABDOMEN: NABS. Soft, NT, ND. No HSM
   EXTREMITIES: No edema or calf pain, 2+ dorsalis pedis/ posterior tibial
   pulses.
   SKIN: No rashes/lesions, ecchymoses.

   throughout. 5/5 strength throughout. [**1-30**]+ reflexes, equal BL. Normal
   coordination. Gait assessment deferred

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:16.3/150.0/1.4, ALT / AST:129/208, Alk Phos
   / T Bili:70/0.3, Ca++:6.7 mg/dL, Mg++:1.7 mg/dL, PO4:5.2 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   51 yo F s/p recent b/l breast reduction c/b infection p/w PEA arrest
   s/p multiple cycles of Atropine/Epi likely [**3-1**] PE s/p thrombolytics on
   pressors, intubated, heparin gtt.
   .
   #. Obstructive Cardiogenic Shock: Pt in cardiogenic shock [**3-1**] PE
   burden, CT scan shows RV dilatation and multiple bilateral PEs. TTE
   showed hypokinetic, dilated RV. LV systolic function intact. Pt is
   likely preload dependent and is responding well to continued IVF.
   Dobutamine was given initially, but pt had tachycardia and decreased
   BPs in response. On levo and neo.
   - would favor IVF boluses to maintain BP rather than pressors
   - wean pressors for goal MAPs >65
   - cortisol pending
   .
   #. Large P.E s/p thrombolytics: Pt noted to have a large PE on CT scan
   likely [**3-1**] immobile status s/p surgery. Due to her PEA arrest she
   underwent thrombolytic therapy which ended at 925. Currently on heparin
   gtt. No e/o DIC; fibrinogen likely low [**3-1**] t-PA.
   - continue heparin gtt with goal PTT 60-80.
   - monitor coags, Fibrinogen, FDP for e/o DIC
   - transfuse 1 unit PRBCs
   - check Hct q4hrs
   - guaiac all stools
   .
   #. s/p PEA arrest: Had 3 episodes, likely [**3-1**] PEs. No e/o cerebral
   ischemic injury although difficult to judge with intubation/sedation.
   - monitor on tele, no events overnight
   .
   #. Tranaminitis: Hepatic congestion [**3-1**] right heart strain vs. ischemic
   hepatitis, degree of elevation more c/w congestion.
   - monitor daily
   .
   #. [**Last Name (un) **]: Cr 1.6, unknown baseline but presumably normal. Likely
   pre-renal in setting of hypotension/hypoperfusion, but could also have
   ATN from same etiology.
   - monitor response with fluids and improved BP
   - urine lytes pending
   .
   #. HCT drop: Patient had Hct drop despite receiving 2 units PRBC, in
   setting of t-PA and supratherapeutic PTT of >150 on heparin gtt.
   Patient did have visible bleeding from bleed surigical sites, diffuse
   oozing and BRBPR, but there is still concern for occult blood loss with
   this degree of Hct drop. Concern would be for RP bleed.
   - non con CT to r/o RP bleed
   - cont q4h Hct checks and transfuse for goal>30
   .
   #. AMS: Pt noted to be unresponsive initially on examination with no
   sedation on board. At OSH she was reported to have non-focal movement
   of her upper extremities. Now alert, responsive, following commands,
   neuro exam grossly intact. Cannot yet entirely rule out brain injury
   from hypoxia/hypoperfusion, but seems reassuring at this point. Pt c/o
   headache overnight but pupils equal and reactive, headache seems to
   have resolved.
   - will continue to monitor neuro exam q4hrs specfically for pupillary
   reaction
   .
   #. ?Pneumomediastinum: On CXR portable there appears to be trace air in
   the mediastinum, suspect this was artifact and not seen on today
s CXR.
   .
   #. ?Catheter wire: On CXR portable there appears to be an artifact that
   could be a threading wire, unclear if this is external or internal
   though on my check after CXR read there appears to be no external wire.
   Oblique view showed artifact had relocated to below the diaphragm,
   highly unlikely that this is internal. Repeat this AM continues to show
   this foreign object vs. artifact.
   - look at scout images for ab CT
   - consider lateral film
   .
   #. s/p intubation: Pt had good p02 on Fi02 50% and weaned down to 40%
   this AM. Patient has good respiratory drive and mental status would
   likely support extubation.  Will keep intubated today to allow more
   aggressive hydration.
   - PSV trial, maintain patient at most comfortable settings
   .
   #. s/p Breast surgery reduction c/b infection: Will try to obtain OSH
   records regarding pt's recent infectious course. Pt noted to have some
   bleeding at right breast surgical site after tPA.
   - cont levaquin for prior wound infection course
   - D/C vanco since prior wound cx grew GNR
   - f/u bld cx
   - continue with pressure dressing over surgical site
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: initiate  TF via  OGT, replete electrolytes (check ionized
   Ca daily with ABG)
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2129-1-24**] 11:49 AM
   16 Gauge - [**2129-1-24**] 11:50 AM
   Multi Lumen - [**2129-1-24**] 01:30 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2129-1-25**] 12:16 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: heparin gtt
   Stress ulcer: IV ppi
   VAP:  VAP bundle
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 2084**] (HCP/Husband): [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10721**] and
   patient
   Code status: FULL
   Disposition:ICU

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old female who underwent recent bilateral breast reduction surgery and developed an infection, leading to a pulmonary embolism (PE) and cardiac arrest. She was resuscitated and intubated, and has been receiving pressors, intubated, and heparin infusions.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Obstructive Cardiogenic Shock: The patient is still in cardiogenic shock due to the PE burden, and her RV dilatation and hypokinetic RV function may lead to further hemodynamic instability.
2. Large P.E s/p thrombolytics: The patient had a large PE and received thrombolytic therapy, which may have caused bleeding complications, including disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
3. s/p PEA arrest: The patient had three episodes of PEA arrest, which may have caused cerebral ischemic injury, although it is difficult to assess with intubation and sedation.
4. Tranaminitis: The patient's elevated liver enzymes may indicate hepatic congestion or ischemic hepatitis, which may worsen if not addressed promptly.
5. HCT drop: The patient's hemoglobin level has dropped despite receiving two units of packed red blood cells, which may indicate occult blood loss or ongoing bleeding complications.
6. AMS: The patient's altered mental status may be due to hypoxia, hypoperfusion, or brain injury, which requires close monitoring and neurologic examination.
7. Pneumomediastinum: The patient's CXR showed trace air in the mediastinum, which may be an artifact or a sign of a more significant condition.
8. Catheter wire: The patient's CXR showed an artifact that could be a threading wire, which requires further investigation.
9. s/p intubation: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but she may still require intubation to allow for aggressive hydration and management of her cardiogenic shock.
10. s/p breast surgery reduction c/b infection: The patient's recent infectious course and bleeding complications at the surgical site require close monitoring and management.

The patient's ICU care plan should focus on addressing these potential complications, including maintaining hemodynamic stability, managing bleeding complications, and optimizing respiratory and neurological status.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 51-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU after a recent bilateral breast reduction surgery, complicated by an infection, which led to a PEA arrest. She was successfully resuscitated and is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. She has a history of pulmonary embolism (PE) and has undergone thrombolytic therapy. Her current condition is characterized by:

* Obstructive cardiogenic shock due to PE burden, with RV dilatation and multiple bilateral PEs on CT scan
* Large PE s/p thrombolytics, with ongoing heparin therapy
* s/p PEA arrest, with possible brain injury from hypoxia/hypoperfusion
* AMS, with initial unresponsiveness and later alertness and responsiveness
* Possible pneumomediastinum and catheter wire artifact on CXR
* Good respiratory drive and response to weaning of pressors

The patient's current medical plan includes:

* Continued IVF boluses to maintain MAPs >65
* Weaning of pressors, with addition of inotropes if necessary
* Monitoring of coags, fibrinogen, FDP, and Hct
* Transfusion of 1 unit PRBCs
* Check for DIC and fibrinogen levels
* Continued heparin gtt with goal PTT 60-80
* Repeat CXR to rule out pneumomediastinum and catheter wire artifact
* Consider PSV trial if otherwise stable
* Continue vanco and levaquin therapy as started as outpatient
* Monitor coags, fibrinogen, FDP, and bleeding at surgical site

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Worsening of cardiogenic shock
* Development of DIC
* Pneumomediastinum or catheter wire artifact
* Brain injury or AMS
* Respiratory failure
* Infection at surgical site
* Bleeding complications from anticoagulation therapy
* Thrombosis or embolism due to heparin therapy

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications and ensure optimal care.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU after suffering a PEA arrest following a bilateral breast reduction surgery. She has a history of infection and was treated with thrombolytics, which may have contributed to her cardiac arrest.

The patient is currently intubated and on pressors, with a goal mean arterial pressure (MAP) of >65 mmHg. She has a large pulmonary embolism (PE) and is at risk for further clotting complications.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 109 beats per minute, blood pressure of 101/54 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%. Her respiratory status is improving, with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute.

The patient's neurological exam is intact, with preserved sensation and strength throughout. She is alert and responsive, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 15.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of creatinine (1.6 mg/dL) and liver enzymes (ALT 129 IU/L, AST 208 IU/L), suggesting end-organ damage from hypoperfusion. Her blood count is normal, with a white blood cell count of 17.8 K/uL and a platelet count of 382 K/uL.

The patient is at risk for several potential medical complications, including:

1. Obstructive cardiogenic shock: The patient's large PE may continue to cause cardiogenic shock, which could worsen her cardiac function and increase her risk of further complications.
2. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's large PE may continue to cause respiratory distress and increase her risk of further clotting complications.
3. End-organ damage: The patient's elevated creatinine and liver enzymes suggest end-organ damage from hypoperfusion, which could worsen her overall condition.
4. Infection: The patient's history of infection and recent surgery increase her risk of developing further infections, which could worsen her condition.
5. Bleeding: The patient's recent thrombolytic therapy and ongoing anticoagulation therapy increase her risk of bleeding complications.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continued IV fluids and pressors to maintain a MAP of >65 mmHg.
2. Monitoring of the patient's cardiac function and respiratory status.
3. Anticoagulation therapy to prevent further clotting complications.
4. Monitoring of the patient's neurological status and potential for brain injury.
5. Consideration of a pulmonary embolism filter to prevent further clotting complications.
6. Monitoring of the patient's liver and kidney function and potential for further end-organ damage.
7. Consideration of further antibiotic therapy to prevent further infections.
8. Monitoring of the patient's bleeding risk and potential for further bleeding complications.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old female who presented with massive pulmonary embolism and PEA arrest. She has made some improvement in her neurological status, responding to verbal stimuli and complaining of a headache overnight. Her oxygenation has improved, and she is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. She has a left-sided effusion and likely consolidation on her chest X-ray.

The patient has several ongoing medical issues, including cardiogenic shock, respiratory failure, and acute renal failure. She is receiving treatment for these conditions, including levophed and neosynephrine for shock, vancomycin and levofloxacin for infections, and heparin for pulmonary embolism.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further cardiac dysfunction, hypotension, and decreased organ perfusion.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further hypoxia, hypercapnia, and respiratory acidosis.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Pulmonary Embolism: The patient's pulmonary embolism may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further lung damage, respiratory failure, and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Infection: The patient's infections, including sepsis, may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further organ dysfunction, septic shock, and potentially life-threatening complications.
6. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's gastrointestinal system may be at risk for complications such as bleeding, perforation, or obstruction due to the use of anticoagulant therapy and the presence of a nasogastric tube.
7. Neurological Complications: The patient's neurological status may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further neurological damage, cognitive impairment, and potentially life-threatening complications.
8. Hemodynamic Instability: The patient's hemodynamic instability may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further hypotension, tachycardia, and potentially life-threatening complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   51 yo F s/p recent b/l breast reduction c/b infection p/w PEA arrest x3
   s/p multiple cycles of Atropine/Epi likely [**3-1**] PE s/p thrombolytics on
   pressors, intubated, heparin gtt.
   .
   #. Obstructive Cardiogenic Shock: Pt in cardiogenic shock [**3-1**] PE
   burden. TTE showed hypokinetic, dilated RV. LV systolic function
   intact. Pt is likely preload dependent and is responds well to IVF. Is
   continuing to require pressors, as BP drops with pain meds. AM cortisol
   wnl.
   - wean pressors for goal MAPs >65
   .
   #. Large PE s/p thrombolytics: Pt noted to have a large PE on CT scan
   likely [**3-1**] immobile status s/p surgery. Due to her PEA arrest she
   underwent thrombolytic therapy on [**1-24**]. Currently on heparin gtt. No
   e/o DIC; fibrinogen likely low [**3-1**] t-PA.
   - continue heparin gtt with goal PTT 60-80.
   - transfuse for goal Hct>30
   - check Hct q4hrs
   - guaiac all stools
   .
   # Anemia: Pt continues to have falling Hct despite transfusions. Source
   of bleeding unclear- unlikely to be all explained by surgical site, CT
   ab neg for RP bleed.
   - hemolysis labs
   - cont q4 Hct checks and transfuse for Hct<30
   .
   #. Tranaminitis: Hepatic congestion [**3-1**] right heart strain vs. ischemic
   hepatitis, degree of elevation more c/w congestion.
   - recheck today
   .
   #. [**Last Name (un) **]: FeNA 0.6. Cr continues to increase after hydration and improved
   hemodynamics, more consistent with ATN caused by
   hypoperfusion/hypotension. CT scan also showed e/o ATN bilaterally.
   - renally dose meds
   - trend Cr and lytes daily
   - consider renal consult if Cr worsens
   .
   #. AMS: alert, responsive, following commands, neuro exam grossly
   intact. Cannot yet entirely rule out brain injury from
   hypoxia/hypoperfusion, but seems reassuring at this point
   - will continue to monitor neuro exam q4hrs specfically for pupillary
   reaction
   .
   #. ?Catheter wire: On CXR portable there appears to be an artifact that
   could be a threading wire, unclear if this is external or internal
   though on my check after CXR read there appears to be no external wire.
   Oblique view showed artifact had relocated to below the diaphragm,
   highly unlikely that this is internal. Repeat this AM continues to show
   this foreign object vs. artifact.
   - look at scout images for ab CT
   - consider lateral film
   .
   #. s/p intubation: - PSV trial
   - SBT today
   .
   #. s/p Breast surgery reduction c/b infection: Will try to obtain OSH
   records regarding pt's recent infectious course. Pt noted to have some
   bleeding at right breast surgical site after tPA.
   - appreciate plastics recs
   - cont levaquin for prior wound infection course
   - f/u bld cx
   - continue with pressure dressing over surgical site
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: initiate  TF via  OGT, replete electrolytes (check ionized
   Ca daily with ABG)

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old female who underwent bilateral breast reduction surgery and developed an infection, leading to a PEA arrest. She received thrombolytic therapy and is currently intubated and on pressors. Her condition is complicated by obstructive cardiogenic shock, large pulmonary embolism, anemia, transaminitis, and acute tubular necrosis (ATN). She has been receiving fluids, blood products, and antibiotics, and is being monitored for potential complications.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications: The patient's cardiogenic shock and large pulmonary embolism increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.
2. Renal Complications: The patient's ATN and anemia may worsen her renal function, leading to acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, or even end-stage renal disease.
3. Infection Complications: The patient's infection and recent surgery increase the risk of developing sepsis, septic shock, or organ failure.
4. Pulmonary Complications: The patient's pulmonary embolism and ATN may worsen her respiratory function, leading to respiratory failure, acute respiratory distress syndrome, or chronic respiratory disease.
5. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's anemia and ATN may worsen her gastrointestinal function, leading to gastrointestinal bleeding, gastrointestinal perforation, or gastrointestinal obstruction.
6. Neurological Complications: The patient's recent hypoxia and hypoperfusion may have caused brain injury, leading to neurological deficits, seizures, or stroke.
7. Hematological Complications: The patient's anemia and thrombolytic therapy may increase the risk of bleeding, hematoma, or disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
8. Metabolic Complications: The patient's anemia and ATN may worsen her metabolic function, leading to electrolyte imbalances, acid-base disorders, or hyperglycemia.

Given the patient's complex medical condition, it is essential to monitor her closely and adjust her treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU after experiencing a PEA arrest following a bilateral breast reduction surgery. She has a history of infection and has undergone thrombolytic therapy.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* She is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode.
* She has a central line, arterial line, and peripheral IV lines.
* She is receiving heparin infusions and has a goal PTT of 60-80.
* She is receiving pressors to maintain her blood pressure, with a goal MAP of >65.
* She has a Foley catheter in place.
* She has a nasogastric tube in place.
* She has a feeding tube inserted through the nose.

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* WBC: 10.7
* Hct: 28.8
* Platelets: 230
* Creatinine: 2.1
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 22
* Glucose: 137
* Potassium: 4.2
* Sodium: 137
* Chloride: 99
* Carbon dioxide: 22
* Calcium: 7.0
* Magnesium: 2.1
* Phosphorus: 4.2

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Obstructive cardiogenic shock
* Large pulmonary embolism
* Anemia
* Tranaminitis
* Acute tubular necrosis (ATN)
* Possible brain injury from hypoxia/hypoperfusion

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Weaning of pressors for goal MAP of >65
* Continuation of heparin infusions with a goal PTT of 60-80
* Transfusion of blood products as needed to maintain a Hct of >30
* Monitoring of laboratory results, including creatinine and electrolytes
* Consideration of renal consult if creatinine worsens
* Monitoring of neuro exam for signs of brain injury
* Consideration of lateral film to rule out internal catheter wire
* Trial of pressure dressing over surgical site
* Continuation of prophylactic medications, including heparin, IV ppi, and VAP bundle

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Further decline in renal function
* Increased risk of bleeding due to heparin therapy
* Development of sepsis or septic shock
* Further decline in cardiac function
* Development of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Development of chronic kidney disease (CKD)
* Development of chronic liver disease (CLD)
* Development of chronic pulmonary disease (CPD)

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old female who suffered cardiac arrest and is currently in the ICU. She has made remarkable improvement in her mental status and oxygenation over the past two days. However, she has persistent hypotension that requires pressor support.

The patient's current vital signs include:

* Temperature: 38C (100.4F)
* Heart rate: 100 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 107/54 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 13 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 99%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus tachycardia

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 8.7 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 10.7 x 10^9/L
* Platelet count: 230 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 2.1 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 22 mg/dL
* Electrolyte levels: sodium 137 mmol/L, potassium 4.2 mmol/L, chloride 25.1 mmol/L, and bicarbonate 22 mmol/L

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Chest X-ray: normal

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient has made significant improvement in her respiratory status and is now tolerating spontaneous breathing trials (SBT) well. The plan is to continue SBT and monitor the patient's response.
* Extubation: The patient is a candidate for extubation if she continues to tolerate SBT well.
* Pain control: The patient will require pain control post-extubation due to likely significant rib fractures and previous pain with infection.
* Additional issues to be addressed: The patient's nutrition, glycemic control, and line care need to be addressed.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient may experience respiratory failure again if she is not extubated or if she experiences a setback in her respiratory status.
* Sepsis: The patient has a history of infection and may be at risk for developing sepsis.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac arrest and hypotension may increase her risk for developing cardiac arrhythmias.
* Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine level and blood urea nitrogen level may indicate renal failure.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of abdominal pain and bleeding may increase her risk for gastrointestinal bleeding.

Overall, the patient's condition is improving, but she still requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU after a recent bilateral breast reduction surgery complicated by infection, which led to a PEA arrest. She was intubated and received multiple cycles of Atropine/Epi, likely due to pulmonary embolism (PE). She was treated with thrombolytics and heparin, and her condition has been unstable.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* She is extubated and breathing on her own, but has a history of respiratory failure.
* She has a falling hemoglobin (Hct) despite transfusions, with a current Hct of 25.9%.
* She has a large PE on CT scan, which is likely immobile due to her recent surgery.
* She has evidence of acute tubular necrosis (ATN) on CT scan, with increasing creatinine (Cr) levels.
* She has transaminitis, with elevated liver enzymes.
* She has acute kidney injury (AKI), with a creatinine level of 2.9 mg/dL.
* She has a history of anemia, and her current hemoglobin level is 8.6 g/dL.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Hemorrhage: The patient's falling Hct and history of bleeding at the surgical site suggest that she is at risk for further bleeding.
2. Pulmonary Embolism: The patient's large PE on CT scan increases her risk of further pulmonary embolism, which can be life-threatening.
3. Acute Tubular Necrosis: The patient's ATN on CT scan and increasing Cr levels suggest that she is at risk for further kidney damage.
4. Transaminitis: The patient's elevated liver enzymes suggest that she may be at risk for further liver damage.
5. Anemia: The patient's low hemoglobin level and history of bleeding suggest that she may be at risk for further anemia.
6. Hypotension: The patient's history of hypotension and low blood pressure suggest that she may be at risk for further hypotension, which can lead to organ dysfunction.
7. Respiratory Failure: The patient's history of respiratory failure and recent intubation suggest that she may be at risk for further respiratory failure.

In summary, this patient is at risk for a range of medical complications, including hemorrhage, pulmonary embolism, acute tubular necrosis, transaminitis, anemia, hypotension, and respiratory failure.

8. Breast Surgical Site Infection: The patient has an infection at the right breast surgical site, which may lead to further complications such as sepsis, abscess formation, and potentially life-threatening outcomes.

Based on these potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent further deterioration and potential life-threatening outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

The patient, a 51-year-old female, is a post-operative patient who underwent bilateral breast reduction surgery. She developed an infection and subsequently suffered a PEA arrest, which led to multiple cycles of atropine and epinephrine. She was intubated and placed on pressors, heparin drip, and thrombolytic therapy. The patient's current condition is complicated by:

1. Anemia: Despite transfusions, the patient's hemoglobin level continues to fall, with unclear bleeding sources.
2. Obstructive Cardiogenic Shock: The patient is in cardiogenic shock due to a large pulmonary embolism (PE) likely caused by immobility and thrombolytic therapy. Her right ventricular function is hypokinetic, and left ventricular function is intact.
3. Large PE s/p thrombolytics: The patient has a large PE on CT scan and is currently on heparin drip. No signs of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) are present.
4. Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN): The patient's creatinine level is increasing, likely due to hypoperfusion/hypotension, and CT scan shows evidence of ATN bilaterally.
5. Transaminitis: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, likely due to hepatic congestion and right heart strain.
6. Acute Myocardial Stunning (AMS): The patient's neuro exam is intact, but there is a possibility of brain injury from hypoxia/hypoperfusion.
7.?Catheter wire: There is an artifact on CXR that may be a threading wire, but further investigation has shown no foreign object.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Further bleeding or hemorrhage due to anemia and unclear bleeding sources.
2. Cardiac complications, such as heart failure or arrhythmias, due to cardiogenic shock and obstructive cardiogenic shock.
3. Renal failure or worsening of ATN, leading to further electrolyte imbalances and acid-base disturbances.
4. Increased risk of infection, particularly in the surgical site, due to immunosuppression and altered immune function.
5. Neurological complications, such as seizures or stroke, due to AMS or hypoxia/hypoperfusion.
6. Pulmonary complications, such as respiratory failure or worsening of pulmonary edema, due to cardiogenic shock and ATN.
7. Gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or perforation, due to transaminitis and ATN.

The patient requires close monitoring and management of these complications to prevent further deterioration and improve her chances of recovery.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2C, heart rate of 94 bpm, and blood pressure of 155/57 mmHg. The patient's oxygen saturation is 100% on nasal cannula at 2L.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin levels decreasing from 25 to 22.4 g/dL, indicating anemia secondary to blood loss
* White blood cell count ranging from 7.4 to 8.6 K/uL, indicating a possible infection
* Platelet count ranging from 119 to 157 K/uL, indicating a possible bleeding disorder
* Creatinine level of 2.9 mg/dL, indicating possible kidney dysfunction
* Lactic acid level of 1.0 mmol/L, indicating possible tissue hypoperfusion
* Calcium level of 7.2 mg/dL, indicating possible hypocalcemia
* Magnesium level of 2.2 mg/dL, indicating possible hypomagnesemia
* Phosphorus level of 3.9 mg/dL, indicating possible hypophosphatemia

The patient's radiology results show:

* A CXR with stable left lower lobe atelectasis and pleural effusion with moderately severe interstitial edema

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Pain control for acute and chronic pain
* Anemia, acute, secondary to blood loss
* Pulmonary embolism, acute
* H/O cardiac arrest
* Hypotension (not shock)
* Alteration in tissue perfusion

Potential medical complications that can arise based on this information include:

* Bleeding disorders due to thrombocytopenia
* Infection due to decreased white blood cell count
* Kidney dysfunction due to decreased creatinine clearance
* Tissue hypoperfusion due to decreased blood pressure and oxygen saturation
* Hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia due to electrolyte imbalance
* Pulmonary embolism due to immobility and hypercoagulability
* Cardiac arrest due to underlying cardiac disease and electrolyte imbalance
* Anemia due to blood loss and decreased production
* Respiratory failure due to atelectasis and pleural effusion

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old female admitted with pulmonary embolus and PEA arrest, currently extubated with ongoing issues of respiratory failure, anemia, renal failure, and altered memory.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38C (100.4F), heart rate of 94 bpm, blood pressure of 145/56 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute. Her oxygen saturation is 99% on nasal cannula, and she has a mild anemia with a hemoglobin level of 8.9 g/dL.

The patient has a substantial increase in urine output, which is likely related to the diuretic therapy. Her electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated potassium level of 4.8 mEq/L.

The patient has a significant left-sided ecchymosis in the femoral area, consistent with a substantial hematoma, which may be contributing to her anemia.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 8.4 K/uL, platelet count of 157 K/uL, and creatinine level of 2.9 mg/dL, indicating ongoing renal failure.

The patient's imaging studies show decreased lung volumes and mild interstitial edema on the chest X-ray.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient will continue incentive spirometry 10 times per hour while awake, and will need to get out of bed today with the aid of physical therapy. Nebulizers will be used to continue respiratory support.
2. Anemia: The patient will have a CT scan of the thigh and groin area to evaluate for blood loss. She will continue to receive blood transfusions as needed, with a goal hemoglobin level of 24 g/dL or higher.
3. Renal failure: The patient will need to follow urine output and fluid balance, with a goal of negative 2-4 liters of urine output per day.
4. Altered memory: The patient's altered memory is likely related to the transient anoxic insult during her PEA arrest. She will need to be monitored for behavior changes.
5. Pain control: The patient will be managed with as-needed Dilaudid for pain.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: Pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and respiratory arrest.
* Anemia: Blood loss, hemolytic anemia, and sepsis.
* Renal failure: Acute tubular necrosis (ATN), chronic kidney disease, and electrolyte imbalances.
* Altered memory: Cognitive decline, dementia, and behavioral changes.
* Pain control: Opioid-induced respiratory depression, constipation, and nausea.

The patient will require close monitoring and management to prevent and address these potential complications.

   g/dL, LDH:494 IU/L, Ca++:7.4 mg/dL, Mg++:2.3 mg/dL, PO4:4.2 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   51 yo F s/p recent b/l breast reduction c/b infection p/w PEA arrest x3
   s/p multiple cycles of Atropine/Epi likely [**3-1**] PE s/p thrombolytics on
   heparin gtt, now of pressors and extubated.
   .
   # Anemia: Pt continues to have falling Hct despite transfusions. Source
   of bleeding unclear- unlikely to be all explained by surgical site, CT
   ab neg for RP bleed.   No signs of hemolysis.  Patient does have
   ecchymosis in left groin (line placed in rt groin).
   - cont q6 Hct checks and transfuse for Hct<25.  Would space out Hct
   checks if next is stable.
   - CT leg not source on our read, await final read.
   - consider rescan of abdomen if Hct continues to fall
   .
   # Respiratory Failure-Patient with poor inspiratory effort and fluid
   overload.  CXR difficult to interpret this AM given
   - OOB to chair yesterday
   - PT consult
   - incentive spirometer, chest PT
   - albuterol/atrovent nebs
   - diuresis
   .
   #. AMS: alert, responsive, following commands, neuro exam grossly
   intact.  Patient perseverative, likely with short term memory deficits
   from hypoxia/hypoperfusion, although it is unclear what her long term
   functional status will be.
   - will continue to monitor neuro exam
   - minimize sedation medications; will space out dilaudid prn
   .
   #. Obstructive Cardiogenic Shock: Pt in cardiogenic shock [**3-1**] PE
   burden. TTE showed hypokinetic, dilated RV. LV systolic function
   intact. Pt is likely preload dependent and is responds well to IVF.
   Now weaned off of pressors, with BP low overnight secondary to pain
   medication but improved BP this morning.
   - will procede with cautious diuresis as patient is thought to be
   grossly volume overloaded,
   - if BP becomes an issue today, can give back some volume.
   .
   #. Large PE s/p thrombolytics: Pt noted to have a large PE on CT scan
   likely [**3-1**] immobile status s/p surgery. Due to her PEA arrest she
   underwent thrombolytic therapy on [**1-24**]. Currently on heparin gtt. No
   e/o DIC; fibrinogen likely low [**3-1**] t-PA.
   - continue heparin gtt with goal PTT 60-80.
   - transfuse for goal Hct>30
   - monitor Hct
   - guaiac all stools
   - hold off on transition to coumadin until Hct stable
   .
   #. [**Last Name (un) **]: FeNA 0.6. Cr continues to increase after hydration and improved
   hemodynamics, more consistent with ATN caused by
   hypoperfusion/hypotension. CT scan also showed e/o ATN bilaterally.
   Cre down slightly today, with BUN up slightly, this may complicate
   diuresis.
   - renally dose meds
   - trend Cr and lytes daily
   - consider renal consult if Cr worsens
   .
   #. Transaminitis: Hepatic congestion [**3-1**] right heart strain vs.
   ischemic hepatitis, degree of elevation more c/w congestion.  Trending
   down today.
   - continues to trend down, this along with better renal function may
   indicate better forward flow.
   .
   #. s/p Breast surgery reduction c/b infection: Pt noted to have some
   bleeding at right breast surgical site after tPA. Plastics following.
   - appreciate plastics recs
   - course of levaquin completed
   - f/u bld cx
   - continue with surgibra/pressure dressing over surgical site
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: clear fluids, will advance to full as tolerated
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   -PICC placed, CVL d/c
d and plan for A-line d/c

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU after experiencing a pulmonary embolism (PE) and cardiac arrest. She underwent thrombolytic therapy and is currently on heparin drip. She has a history of breast reduction surgery, which was complicated by infection. The patient is currently experiencing respiratory failure, anemia, obstructive cardiogenic shock, and acute tubular necrosis (ATN).

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.9C, heart rate of 107 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 141/64 mmHg. She is receiving oxygen therapy and has a SpO2 of 93%. Her respiratory status is compromised, with a diffusely wheezy anterior lung exam.

The patient has a significant amount of fluid overload, with a total fluid intake of 1,220 mL and a total fluid output of 4,745 mL. She has a large amount of blood products, including platelets, and is receiving IV fluids.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.2 g/dL and a hematocrit level of 25.4%. Her platelet count is 119,000/L, and her blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 39 mg/dL.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised, and she is at risk for further respiratory decline.
2. Anemia: The patient's anemia is not fully explained by her surgical site bleeding, and she may require further transfusions.
3. Obstructive cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiac output is compromised, and she may require further inotropic support.
4. Acute tubular necrosis: The patient's renal function is compromised, and she may require further management of her electrolyte levels.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, and she may be at risk for bleeding complications.
6. Infection: The patient has a history of breast reduction surgery complicated by infection, and she may be at risk for further infection.
7. Cardiac arrest: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest, and she may be at risk for further cardiac events.

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and provide oxygen therapy as needed.
2. Continue to transfuse blood products as needed to manage the patient's anemia.
3. Continue to manage the patient's cardiac output with inotropic support as needed.
4. Continue to manage the patient's renal function with diuresis and electrolyte management.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's platelet count and provide platelet transfusions as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and provide electrolyte management as needed.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's infection risk and provide antibiotics as needed.

   Assessment and Plan
   51 yo F s/p recent b/l breast reduction c/b infection p/w PEA arrest x3
   s/p multiple cycles of Atropine/Epi likely [**3-1**] PE s/p thrombolytics on
   heparin gtt, now of pressors and extubated.
   .
   # Anemia: Pt continues to have falling Hct despite transfusions. Source
   of bleeding unclear- unlikely to be all explained by surgical site, CT
   ab neg for RP bleed.   No signs of hemolysis.  Patient does have
   ecchymosis in left groin (line placed in rt groin).
   - cont q6 Hct checks and transfuse for Hct<25.  Would space out Hct
   checks if next is stable.
   - CT leg not source on our read, await final read.
   - consider rescan of abdomen if Hct continues to fall
   .
   # Respiratory Failure-Patient with poor inspiratory effort and fluid
   overload.  CXR difficult to interpret this AM given
   - OOB to chair yesterday
   - PT consult
   - incentive spirometer, chest PT
   - albuterol/atrovent nebs
   - diuresis
   .
   #. AMS: alert, responsive, following commands, neuro exam grossly
   intact.  Patient perseverative, likely with short term memory deficits
   from hypoxia/hypoperfusion, although it is unclear what her long term
   functional status will be.
   - will continue to monitor neuro exam
   - minimize sedation medications; will space out dilaudid prn
   .
   #. Obstructive Cardiogenic Shock: Pt in cardiogenic shock [**3-1**] PE
   burden. TTE showed hypokinetic, dilated RV. LV systolic function
   intact. Pt is likely preload dependent and is responds well to IVF.
   Now weaned off of pressors, with BP low overnight secondary to pain
   medication but improved BP this morning.
   - will procede with cautious diuresis as patient is thought to be
   grossly volume overloaded,
   - if BP becomes an issue today, can give back some volume.
   .
   #. Large PE s/p thrombolytics: Pt noted to have a large PE on CT scan
   likely [**3-1**] immobile status s/p surgery. Due to her PEA arrest she
   underwent thrombolytic therapy on [**1-24**]. Currently on heparin gtt. No
   e/o DIC; fibrinogen likely low [**3-1**] t-PA.
   - continue heparin gtt with goal PTT 60-80.
   - transfuse for goal Hct>30
   - monitor Hct
   - guaiac all stools
   - hold off on transition to coumadin until Hct stable
   .
   #. [**Last Name (un) **]: FeNA 0.6. Cr continues to increase after hydration and improved
   hemodynamics, more consistent with ATN caused by
   hypoperfusion/hypotension. CT scan also showed e/o ATN bilaterally.
   Cre down slightly today, with BUN up slightly, this may complicate
   diuresis.
   - renally dose meds
   - trend Cr and lytes daily
   - consider renal consult if Cr worsens
   .
   #. Transaminitis: Hepatic congestion [**3-1**] right heart strain vs.
   ischemic hepatitis, degree of elevation more c/w congestion.  Trending
   down today.
   - continues to trend down, this along with better renal function may
   indicate better forward flow.
   .
   #. s/p Breast surgery reduction c/b infection: Pt noted to have some
   bleeding at right breast surgical site after tPA. Plastics following.
   - appreciate plastics recs
   - course of levaquin completed
   - f/u bld cx
   - continue with surgibra/pressure dressing over surgical site

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old female who underwent bilateral breast reduction surgery and developed an infection, leading to a pulmonary embolism (PE) and subsequent cardiac arrest. She was resuscitated and received thrombolytic therapy, but continues to experience hemodynamic instability. She is currently in the ICU with ongoing respiratory failure, anemia, and acute kidney injury (ATN). She has a history of bleeding at the surgical site, and her labs show evidence of liver dysfunction and transaminitis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hemorrhage: The patient's anemia and ongoing bleeding at the surgical site may lead to further hemorrhage, which could exacerbate her hemodynamic instability.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if her fluid overload is not effectively managed, leading to further respiratory distress.
3. Acute Kidney Injury (ATN): The patient's ATN may progress if her kidney function does not improve, leading to further electrolyte imbalances and potential need for dialysis.
4. Liver Dysfunction: The patient's liver dysfunction may worsen if her ATN progresses, leading to further elevation of liver enzymes and potential liver failure.
5. Cardiac Complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and ongoing hemodynamic instability may lead to further cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock or arrhythmias.
6. Infection: The patient's infection at the surgical site may spread and lead to sepsis, which could further complicate her medical condition.
7. Thrombotic Complications: The patient's use of thrombolytic therapy may increase her risk of thrombotic complications, such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE).

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamic status and adjust fluid management accordingly.
2. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory failure with oxygen therapy and diuresis.
3. Monitor the patient's kidney function and adjust her renal dose medications as needed.
4. Continue to manage the patient's liver dysfunction with close monitoring of liver enzymes and potential need for liver support.
5. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust her cardiac medications as needed.
6. Continue to manage the patient's infection at the surgical site with antibiotics and wound care.
7. Monitor the patient's thrombotic risk and adjust her anticoagulation therapy as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after suffering a pulmonary embolism (PE) and cardiopulmonary arrest (CPA) in the field. He was resuscitated and received thrombolysis.

The patient remains extubated and off vasopressors. He is complaining of generalized skin and body "soreness," chest pain (attributed to chest compressions), and upper back pain (chronic). He denies dyspnea.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2C (99F), heart rate of 103 bpm, and blood pressure of 175/65 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 96% on room air.

The patient has a history of penicillin allergy and anaphylaxis, as well as a history of Macrobid (Nitrofurantoin/Nitrofuran Mac) allergy with unknown severity. He is currently receiving heparin infusion for anticoagulation.

The patient's physical examination is notable for bilateral dressings over his breasts, soft and non-tender abdomen, and purposeful movement. His neurological examination is normal, with no signs of sedation or paralysis.

Laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.0 g/dL, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and aspartate transaminase (AST) levels. His coagulation profile is abnormal, with a prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT) and international normalized ratio (INR).

Potential medical complications that may arise in this patient include:

1. Bleeding: Due to the patient's coagulopathy and anticoagulation therapy, there is a risk of bleeding, particularly at the site of the femoral central line.
2. Renal failure: The patient's acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and pre-existing renal failure may worsen if he does not receive adequate fluid management and dialysis.
3. Infection: The patient's incision infections and chronic back pain may lead to further complications, such as sepsis or abscesses.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's history of respiratory failure and PEA arrest may increase his risk of respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
5. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's poor oral intake and potential for further bleeding may lead to nutritional deficiencies, particularly protein-energy malnutrition.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, it is essential to continue monitoring his vital signs, laboratory results, and physical examination findings closely. Adjustments to his anticoagulation therapy, fluid management, and nutritional support may be necessary to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after experiencing a pulmonary embolism (PE) and subsequent cardiopulmonary arrest (CPA). The patient remains extubated and off vasopressors, but continues to experience chest pain and upper back pain, which is attributed to the CPR. The patient's respiratory status has improved, but he remains at risk for further complications.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, which is attributed to acute blood loss, and renal failure, which is attributed to acute tubular necrosis (ATN) in the context of the CPA. The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, and he is at risk for further blood loss due to the femoral central line.

The patient's medical history includes a history of immobility following surgery, which is a predisposing factor for the development of PEs. The patient is receiving anticoagulation therapy and is at risk for bleeding.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pulmonary Embolism: The patient is at risk for further PEs, especially given his immobility and the presence of a central line.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status remains critical, and he is at risk for further respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
3. Renal Failure: The patient's renal function is impaired, and he is at risk for further deterioration, which could lead to end-stage renal disease.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is a concern, and he may require further transfusions to maintain adequate hemoglobin levels.
5. Bleeding: The patient is at risk for bleeding due to his anemia and the presence of a central line.
6. Infection: The patient's breast reduction surgery has complicated by incision infections, and he is at risk for further infections, such as pneumonia or sepsis.
7. Nutritional Deficiencies: The patient's poor intake is a concern, and he may require nutritional support to maintain adequate nutritional status.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's assessment and plan include:

1. Respiratory support: The patient's respiratory status will be monitored closely, and he will be maintained on oxygen therapy to maintain a SaO2 > 90%.
2. Anticoagulation therapy: The patient will continue to receive anticoagulation therapy to prevent further PEs.
3. Anemia management: The patient's anemia will be monitored closely, and he may require further transfusions to maintain adequate hemoglobin levels.
4. Renal support: The patient's renal function will be monitored closely, and he may require further support, such as dialysis, to manage his renal failure.
5. Infection prevention: The patient's breast reduction surgery will be monitored closely for signs of infection, and he will receive prophylactic antibiotics to prevent further infections.
6. Nutritional support: The patient's nutritional status will be monitored closely, and he may require nutritional support to maintain adequate nutritional status.
7. Activity level: The patient's activity level will be monitored closely, and he will be encouraged to participate in activities, such as sitting in a chair, to maintain his physical function.

   condition of immobility following surgery.  Hold anticoagulation,
   resume once bleeding issue resolved.

   recovery, but may be left with chronic insufficiency.
   NAUSEA -- attributed to narcotics (in part), and other medications.
   Monitor symptoms and abdominal exam.  Provide symptomatic relief.
   CHEST PAIN -- attributed to chest compressions (CPR).  Symptomatic
   relief.

   management.

   BREAST REDUCTION SURGERY -- complicated by incision infections -->

   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT -- PO, but poor intake.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old male who was transferred to the ICU for management of worsening anemia and acute GI/GU bleed. The patient had a previous PEA arrest attributed to bilateral pulmonary emboli, which was treated with lysis. He is currently on heparin, but it was held due to concerns about bleeding.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamic status: Stable, with a blood pressure of 178/64 mmHg and a heart rate of 105 bpm.
* Respiratory status: Stable, with a SpO2 of 95% and a respiratory rate of 28 inspirations per minute.
* Cardiovascular status: Stable, with a sinus tachycardia rhythm.
* Gastrointestinal status: The patient has a significant amount of blood and clots in his bed sheets, and he is at risk for further bleeding into his thigh or retroperitoneal space. He has also had a recent CT scan showing inflammation in the small intestine, which may indicate ischemic bowel.
* Renal status: The patient has chronic kidney disease and is at risk for further kidney damage due to his recent PEA arrest and thrombolysis.
* Neurological status: The patient is awake and oriented to person, place, and time, but he is unable to stand due to his edema.
* Nutritional status: The patient is receiving parenteral nutrition and has poor oral intake.

The patient's medical complications include:

* Acute gastrointestinal bleed
* Acute kidney injury
* Chronic kidney disease
* Chronic pain
* Ischemic bowel
* Pulmonary embolism
* Renal failure
* Thrombocytopenia

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 9.0 g/dL
* Hematocrit: 23.3%
* Platelet count: 119 K/uL
* White blood cell count: 7.4 K/uL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 24 mEq/L
* Creatinine: 3.0 mg/dL
* Glucose: 98 mg/dL
* Calcium: 7.6 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.5 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.8 mg/dL

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Monitoring of his hemodynamic status and respiratory status
* Management of his acute gastrointestinal bleed, including endoscopy and possible surgery
* Management of his acute kidney injury, including dialysis and fluid restriction
* Management of his chronic kidney disease, including medication and diet
* Management of his chronic pain, including medication and physical therapy
* Monitoring of his nutritional status and providing parenteral nutrition as needed
* Monitoring of his neurological status and providing physical therapy as needed.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Further bleeding into his thigh or retroperitoneal space
* Ischemic bowel
* Pulmonary embolism
* Renal failure
* Thrombocytopenia
* Infection
* Sepsis
* Organ failure

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is ICU.

   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 51F s/p recent PEA arrest from massive PE now
   presenting to the [**Hospital Unit Name 4**] in ther setting of falling HCTs and BRBPR in the
   setting of a Heparin gtt.
   .
   #: HCT Drop: Pt remains hemodynamically stable with SBPs in 160s. This
   AM she had two more bloody bowel movements, and despite transfusions
   she appearrs to have stagnated at a hct of 27.  At this point her blood
   loss appearrs to be a combination of GI and breast.

 refusing to scope, suggested tagged red cell scan which

   - discuss IVC filter with IR
   - continue heparin for now, if hemodynamically unstable reverse with
   protamine.

   #: Hypertension: Pt on Lisinopril 20mg as outpatient. Have held
   antihypertensives while in house given given Hct drop and PE. Continue
   to trend.
   - Restart ACEi at lower dose once Hct stabilizes and renal function
   improves
   - Will tolerate higher blood pressures in the setting of her GI bleed
   .

   deficits from hypoxia/hypoperfusion, sedation.   Concern for some ICU
   delerium at night
   - Continue to monitor and trend
   - will continue to monitor neuro exam
   - minimize sedation medications; will space out dilaudid prn
   - haldol PRN for agitation
   .
   #: Bilateral Breast Reduction Sugery: Being following by plastics. Per
   report hematoma at right breast.

   - Compressive dressing w/ 4x4s fan folded Kerlix and tape. Then two
   kerlix rolls applied over medial aspect Rt Breast and abdominal binder

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 51-year-old female who presented to the hospital after a recent PEA arrest due to a massive pulmonary embolism (PE). She has been experiencing bloody bowel movements and is currently being managed with heparin infusions. Her hemoglobin (HCT) levels have been declining, and she has been transfused with blood products. The patient has also undergone bilateral breast reduction surgery and has a right breast hematoma.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **GI Bleeding:** The patient's continued bloody bowel movements and declining HCT levels indicate ongoing GI bleeding. This could lead to further blood loss, hypovolemic shock, and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. **Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT):** The patient is receiving heparin infusions, which can increase the risk of HIT, a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by thrombocytopenia, thrombosis, and hemorrhage.
3. **Coagulopathy:** The patient's prolonged prothrombin time (PT), partial thromboplastin time (PTT), and international normalized ratio (INR) suggest a coagulopathy, which could increase the risk of bleeding complications.
4. **Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN):** The patient's creatinine (Cr) levels are increasing, and her urine output (UOP) is good, suggesting ATN, a potentially life-threatening complication of acute kidney injury.
5. **Infection:** The patient's elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and presence of a right breast hematoma increase the risk of infection.
6. **Sepsis:** The patient's elevated WBC and Cr levels, as well as her hypotensive event, increase the risk of sepsis, a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by organ dysfunction and hypoperfusion.
7. **ICU Delirium:** The patient's altered mental status and short-term memory deficits suggest the possibility of ICU delirium, which can increase the risk of complications and mortality.
8. **Pulmonary Embolism (PE):** The patient's previous PE and ongoing heparin therapy increase the risk of recurrent PE, which can be life-threatening.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamic status and adjust heparin therapy as necessary.
2. Consider repeat tagged red cell scan to identify the source of bleeding.
3. Continue to trend the patient's HCT levels and transfuse as necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust therapy accordingly.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust sedation therapy as necessary.
6. Consider restarting ACE inhibitors at a lower dose once the patient's HCT levels stabilize and renal function improves.
7. Monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust therapy accordingly.
8. Consider prophylactic antibiotics to prevent infection.
9. Monitor the patient's temperature and adjust therapy accordingly.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and adjust therapy accordingly.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be identified:

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old female who presented to the hospital with a massive pulmonary embolism (PE) and subsequent cardiac arrest. She was resuscitated and has been admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for further management. The patient has been experiencing bleeding from her breast and gastrointestinal tract, and has had multiple bloody bowel movements. She has been receiving heparin infusion for anticoagulation, and has been transfused with blood products to address her anemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Bleeding: The patient's bleeding from her breast and gastrointestinal tract is a significant concern, and may lead to further blood loss, hypovolemic shock, and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin levels have been declining, and she has been transfused with blood products. However, her anemia may continue to worsen if the bleeding is not controlled, which could lead to further complications.
3. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count has been decreasing, which could lead to bleeding complications, particularly if she continues to experience bleeding from her breast and gastrointestinal tract.
4. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine levels have been increasing, which could indicate AKI. This could be related to her hypotensive event, and may require further evaluation and management.
5. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure has been elevated, which could be related to her bleeding and anemia. This could lead to further complications, such as cardiac issues and increased bleeding.
6. Neurological Complications: The patient has been experiencing neurological symptoms, including altered mental status and short-term memory deficits. This could be related to her hypoxia/hypoperfusion, sedation, and potential ICU delirium.
7. Sepsis: The patient's bleeding and potential bacterial contamination of her wounds could lead to sepsis, which could be life-threatening.
8. Wound Complications: The patient's breast wound has been packed and wrapped with a compressive dressing, but there is a risk of further complications, such as wound infection, dehiscence, or hematoma.
9. Respiratory Complications: The patient's respiratory status has been stable, but there is a risk of further complications, such as respiratory failure, if her bleeding is not controlled and she experiences further hypovolemic shock.

In summary, the patient is at high risk for further complications related to her bleeding, anemia, thrombocytopenia, AKI, hypertension, neurological symptoms, sepsis, wound complications, and respiratory complications. Close monitoring and management of these complications will be essential to ensure the patient's safety and improve her outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old female who has undergone bilateral breast reduction surgery and is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to a massive pulmonary embolism (PE) and subsequent hypotensive event. She has been experiencing hemodynamically stable vital signs, but has had significant blood loss, including bloody bowel movements and a right breast hematoma.

The patient's laboratory results show a drop in hemoglobin (Hb) levels, with a current Hb of 9.6 g/dL, and a hematocrit (Hct) of 27%. Her platelet count is 123 x 10^9/L, and her blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine (Cr) levels are elevated.

The patient's medical conditions and potential complications include:

1. Massive PE with hypotensive event, which may have caused hypoperfusion and potential organ damage.
2. Significant blood loss, including bloody bowel movements and a right breast hematoma, which may be related to the PE or other underlying conditions.
3. Hypertension, which may be related to the PE or other underlying conditions.
4. Acute kidney injury (AKI), which may be related to the PE, hypotensive event, or other underlying conditions.
5. Potential for sepsis or organ failure due to the patient's critical illness.

The patient's current medications include:

1. Heparin gtt for DVT prophylaxis and treatment of PE.
2. Pantoprazole (Protonix) for stress ulcer prophylaxis.
3. Haloperidol (Haldol) for sedation.
4. IV fluids for hydration and blood pressure management.
5. Blood products, including packed red blood cells (PRBCs), for transfusion.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

1. Maintenance of access via Power PICC line.
2. Attempt to gain a 18g peripheral intravenous (PIV) line.
3. q4Hct checks to monitor blood loss and Hct levels.
4. GI consult to discuss potential sources of bleeding and treatment options.
5. CT torso to evaluate for any other potential sources of bleeding.
6. Consideration of repeat tagged red cell scan to identify source of bleeding.
7. IV prophylaxis for stress ulcers.
8. Pain management with narcotics.
9. DVT prophylaxis with pneumatic boots.
10. Bowel regimen.
11. Monitor for signs of sepsis or organ failure.

The patient's current disposition is ICU care, with a code status of full code.

   Assessment and Plan
   51 yof s/p PEA arrest (in field) attritubed to bilateral pulmonary
   emboli (lysis), now with acute GI bleed.
   ANEMIA -- attributed to acute blood loss.  Appears to be GI (lower
   source).  Blood loss also through breast incision sites, and at risk
   for blood loss into thigh (sight of femoral central line).  Concern for
   ishemic bowel (noted inflammation on most recent CT scan).  No evidence
   for hemolysis.  Ecchymosis (chest, arms, right groin) accounts for some
   blood loss.  Monitor serial abd exam, serial Hct, maintain Hct >28.  GI
   consultation in place.  General surgery to F/U.  Hold anticoagulation
   pending evaluation.
   GI bleed
 unclear source, but concerns include diverticular bleed,
   ischemic colitis, or tumor.  Not yet identifed site.  If persistent
   bleeding (off heparin) would proceed with repeat bleeding scan, and
   consider angiography +/- embolizattion.  GI service and Surgery
   following.
   PULMONARY EMBOLI -- s/p arrest and thrombolysis.  Predisposing
   condition of immobility following surgery.  WouldHold anticoagulation,
   resume once bleeding issue resolved.  If unable to continue
   anticoagulation, would place IVC filter (removable).
   NAUSEA
 evidence for ileus (gastric and proximal small bowel air-fluid
   level).  Unfortunately pt. self d/c
d OGT.  Will encourage pt to accept
   replacement of NGT.
   RENAL FAILURE -- attributed to ATN in context of PEA arrest.  Slow
   recovery, but may be left with chronic insufficiency.
   NAUSEA -- attributed to narcotics (in part), and other medications.
   Monitor symptoms and abdominal exam.  Provide symptomatic relief.
   CHEST PAIN -- attributed to chest compressions (CPR).  Symptomatic
   relief.
   BACK PAIN -- upper, chronic.  Continue medications to optimize pain
   management.
   FLUIDS -- net volume overloaded from resussitation.  Goal net negative
   2 L over next 24 hrs.
   BREAST REDUCTION SURGERY -- complicated by incision infections, now
   with bleeding complications while on heparin --> monitored by Plastic
   Surgery.  Dressing changes.
   ALTERED MENTAL STATUS
 concern for arrest-associated encephalopathy.
   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT -- PO, but poor intake.
   ACTIVITY -- encourage OOB to chair (with assist).

   Assessment and Plan
   51 yof s/p PEA arrest (in field) attritubed to bilateral pulmonary
   emboli (lysis), now with acute GI bleed.
   ANEMIA -- attributed to acute blood loss.  Appears to be GI (lower
   source).  Blood loss also through breast incision sites, and at risk
   for blood loss into thigh (sight of femoral central line).  Concern for
   ishemic bowel (noted inflammation on most recent CT scan).  No evidence
   for hemolysis.  Ecchymosis (chest, arms, right groin) accounts for some
   blood loss.  Monitor serial abd exam, serial Hct, maintain Hct >28.  GI
   consultation in place.  General surgery to F/U.  Hold anticoagulation
   pending evaluation.
   GI bleed
 unclear source, but concerns include diverticular bleed,
   ischemic colitis, or tumor.  Not yet identifed site.  If persistent
   bleeding (off heparin) would proceed with repeat bleeding scan, and
   consider angiography +/- embolizattion.  GI service and Surgery
   following.
   PULMONARY EMBOLI -- s/p arrest and thrombolysis.  Predisposing
   condition of immobility following surgery.  WouldHold anticoagulation,
   resume once bleeding issue resolved.  If unable to continue
   anticoagulation, would place IVC filter (removable).
   NAUSEA
 evidence for ileus (gastric and proximal small bowel air-fluid
   level).  Unfortunately pt. self d/c
d OGT.  Will encourage pt to accept
   replacement of NGT.
   RENAL FAILURE -- attributed to ATN in context of PEA arrest.  Slow
   recovery, but may be left with chronic insufficiency.
   NAUSEA -- attributed to narcotics (in part), and other medications.
   Monitor symptoms and abdominal exam.  Provide symptomatic relief.
   CHEST PAIN -- attributed to chest compressions (CPR).  Symptomatic
   relief.
   BACK PAIN -- upper, chronic.  Continue medications to optimize pain
   management.
   FLUIDS -- net volume overloaded from resussitation.  Goal net negative
   2 L over next 24 hrs.
   BREAST REDUCTION SURGERY -- complicated by incision infections, now
   with bleeding complications while on heparin --> monitored by Plastic
   Surgery.  Dressing changes.
   ALTERED MENTAL STATUS
 concern for arrest-associated encephalopathy.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old individual who was admitted to the ICU after a PEA arrest attributed to bilateral pulmonary emboli (lysis). The patient has since developed an acute gastrointestinal bleed, which is unclear in its source but is suspected to be related to diverticular bleed, ischemic colitis, or tumor.

The patient has a complex medical history, including a recent breast reduction surgery complicated by incision infections and bleeding complications while on heparin. They also have a history of anemia, which is attributed to acute blood loss.

The patient is currently receiving total 6 units of packed red blood cells over the past 24 hours, and is being monitored for further bleeding. They are also being treated for nausea, renal failure, and altered mental status, which is suspected to be related to arrest-associated encephalopathy.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Hemorrhagic shock: Due to the patient's ongoing bleeding, there is a risk of developing hemorrhagic shock, which can lead to organ failure and death.
2. Sepsis: The patient's incision infections and bleeding complications increase the risk of developing sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) increase the risk of developing respiratory failure, which can lead to death.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of PEA arrest and pulmonary emboli increase the risk of developing cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and history of encephalopathy increase the risk of developing neurological complications, such as seizures and stroke.
6. Renal failure: The patient's ongoing renal failure and history of acute tubular necrosis (ATN) increase the risk of developing chronic kidney disease and end-stage renal disease.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's ongoing gastrointestinal bleed and history of anemia increase the risk of developing gastrointestinal complications, such as perforation and bleeding.

In order to manage these potential complications, the patient should be closely monitored for signs of bleeding, sepsis, respiratory failure, cardiac complications, neurological complications, renal failure, and gastrointestinal complications. The patient should also receive appropriate medical treatment, including antibiotics, anticoagulation therapy, and pain management.

   51 yof s/p PEA arrest (in field) attritubed to bilateral pulmonary

   ANEMIA -- attributed to acute blood loss.  Appears to be GI (lower

   for blood loss into thigh (sight of femoral central line).  Concern for
   ishemic bowel (noted inflammation on most recent CT scan).  No evidence
   for hemolysis.  Ecchymosis (chest, arms, right groin) accounts for some
   blood loss.  Plan check NGT lavage to assess for UGI bleeding source.
   Monitor serial abd exam, serial Hct, maintain Hct >28.  GI consultation
   in place.  Repeat ABD/pelvic CT scan.  General surgery to F/U.  Hold

   GI bleed
 unclear source, but concerns include diverticular bleed,

   bleeding (off heparin) would proceed with repeat bleeding scan, and
   consider angiography +/- embolizattion.  GI service and Surgery
   following.

   resume once bleeding issue resolved.
   NAUSEA
 evidence for ileus (gastric and proximal small bowel air-fluid
   level).  Unfortunately pt. self d/c
d OGT.  Will encourage pt to accept
   replacement of NGT.
   RENAL FAILURE -- attributed to ATN in context of PEA arrest.  Slow
   recovery, but may be left with chronic insufficiency.
   NAUSEA -- attributed to narcotics (in part), and other medications.
   Monitor symptoms and abdominal exam.  Provide symptomatic relief.
   CHEST PAIN -- attributed to chest compressions (CPR).  Symptomatic
   relief.
   BACK PAIN -- upper, chronic.  Continue medications to optimize pain
   management.
   FLUIDS -- net volume overloaded from resussitation.  Goal net negative
   2 L over next 24 hrs.
   BREAST REDUCTION SURGERY -- complicated by incision infections, now

   Surgery.  Dressing changes.

 concern for arrest-associated encephalopathy.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old individual who was admitted to the ICU after a PEA arrest attributed to bilateral pulmonary emboli, and is now experiencing an acute GI bleed. The patient's bleeding is attributed to anemia due to acute blood loss, with concerns for ischemic bowel, diverticular bleed, or tumor. The bleeding source is unclear, but the patient's abdominal exam is normal, and there is no evidence of hemolysis.

The patient's medical history includes a recent breast reduction surgery, which has been complicated by incision infections and bleeding complications while on heparin. The patient's mental status is altered, with perseveration and confusion, which is not typical of their baseline state.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.6 g/dL, and a platelet count of 123. Other lab results include elevated liver enzymes, kidney function tests, and coagulation studies.

The patient's physical examination reveals a soft, non-tender abdomen, with bowel sounds present. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.9C, heart rate of 98 bpm, and blood pressure of 161/65 mmHg.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Hemorrhagic shock: The patient's bleeding is significant, and they are at risk of developing hemorrhagic shock if not properly managed.
2. Ischemic bowel: The patient's altered mental status and abdominal pain suggest the possibility of ischemic bowel, which can lead to bowel necrosis and perforation.
3. Kidney injury: The patient's renal failure is attributed to ATN in the context of PEA arrest, and they may be at risk of developing chronic kidney disease.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's altered mental status and respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute suggest the possibility of respiratory failure.
5. Sepsis: The patient's incision infections and altered mental status suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ failure.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's GI bleed is ongoing, and they are at risk of developing gastrointestinal bleeding complications, such as hemorrhagic shock or bowel perforation.
7. Coagulopathy: The patient's bleeding complications while on heparin suggest the possibility of coagulopathy, which can lead to bleeding complications.
8. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's poor intake and altered mental status suggest the possibility of nutritional deficiencies, which can lead to complications such as sepsis or multi-organ failure.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Monitoring of serial abdominal exams and hemoglobin levels to assess for bleeding and anemia.
2. Repeat abdominal and pelvic CT scans to identify the bleeding source.
3. GI consultation and general surgery follow-up to evaluate the bleeding source and plan further management.
4. Hold anticoagulation pending evaluation and bleeding management.
5. Encourage the patient to accept replacement of the NGT to assess for UGI bleeding source.
6. Monitor symptoms and abdominal exam to assess for nausea and ileus.
7. Provide symptomatic relief for nausea and pain.
8. Optimize pain management with medications.
9. Encourage out-of-bed activity with assist.
10. Continue nutritional support with PO, but poor intake.

The patient's code status is full code, and their disposition is ICU. The patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications and improve outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old female who presented to the ICU with a sudden onset of lower gastrointestinal bleeding (LGIB) and bleeding from her right breast. She had a recent pulmonary embolism (PE) and was started on therapeutic heparin. Despite transfusions, her hemoglobin (Hb) levels have stagnated at 27-30%. A repeat tagged RBC scan showed a sigmoid bleed. The patient has been placed on an IVC filter and is being managed with a combination of medical and surgical interventions.

Potential medical complications:

1. Continued bleeding from the sigmoid colon, which could lead to hypovolemic shock and organ failure.
2. Development of acute kidney injury (AKI) due to hypotension, hypoperfusion, and potential nephrotoxins.
3. Complications from the IVC filter, such as pulmonary embolism or filter migration.
4. Wound infection or hematoma at the right breast, which could lead to sepsis or abscess formation.
5. ICU-acquired delirium, which could worsen the patient's overall condition and increase the risk of complications.
6. Respiratory failure due to hypoxia, which could be exacerbated by the patient's underlying lung disease.
7. Cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock, due to the patient's underlying cardiac disease and potential hypotension.
8. Nutritional deficiencies, particularly protein-calorie malnutrition, due to the patient's inability to take oral nutrition and potential increased energy expenditure.
9. Gastrointestinal complications, such as ileus or perforation, due to the patient's underlying gastrointestinal disease and potential surgery.
10. Infection, particularly sepsis, due to the patient's underlying comorbidities and potential invasive procedures.
